bestBHT.bht: The verse suggests a feeling of isolation on the part of Elijah, who proclaimed, I only am left. The word soul in this context refers to individual life and the seat of one's personality. The altars being dug down represented a complete destruction, indicating a time of great distress and declension in religion. The plural form of altars points to the high places in Israel, where Jehovah was publicly worshiped. Overall, Elijah's statement expressed not just the belief that he was the only prophet remaining, but also the only true worshiper of Jehovah.

Albert Barnes: The fact was true that they had killed the prophets, etc.; 1 Kings 18:4, 1 Kings 18:13; but the inference which Elijah seems to have drawn from it, that there were no pious people in the nation, was not well founded.

And digged down - Altars, by the Law of Moses, were required to be made of earth or unhewn stones; Exodus 20:24-25. Hence, the expression to dig them down means completely to demolish or destroy them.

There could scarcely be conceived a time of greater distress and declension in religion than this. It has not often happened that so many things that were disheartening have occurred to the church at the same period of time.
Marvin Vincent: Life [ψυχην] . From yucw to breathe or blow. In classical usage it signifies life in the distinctness of individual existence, especially of man, occasionally of brutes. Hence, generally, the life of the individual.

Soul [ψυχη] , of itself, does not constitute personality, but only when it is the soul of a human being. Human personality is derived from spirit [πνευμα] , and finds expression in soul or life [ψυχη].

Yuch soul is thus: 1. The individual life, the seat of the personality. 2. The subject of the life, the person in which it dwells. 3. The mind as the sentient principle, the seat of sensation and desire.
Philip Schaff: The plural points to the altars as the high places in the kingdom of Israel where Elijah lived. Although it was originally forbidden to erect such altars, they became the only places in Israel where Jehovah was publicly worshipped.
The language of Elijah meant that he was the only prophet left; while the transposition of the clauses suggests here the further notion: I am the only true worshipper of Jehovah.
It is not necessary to suppose that the Apostle has departed from the original sense.
Archibald T. Robertson: They have digged down (κατεσκαψαν). First aorist active indicative of κατασκαπτω, to dig under or down.
Altars (θυσιαστηρια). Late word (LXX, Philo, Josephus, N.T. eccl. writers) from θυσιαζω, to sacrifice.
It is not possible to draw a clear distinction between ψυχη (soul) and πνευμα (spirit).
John Gill: Lord, they have killed thy prophets... This sin of slaying the prophets of the Lord is charged upon the Jews by Christ
And digged down thine altars... the pulling of them down was done in contempt of them, and of the worship of God
I am left alone... imagining that he was the only person in Israel, that had a true zeal for the Lord of hosts

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse suggests a feeling of isolation on the part of Elijah, who proclaimed, I only am left. The word soul in this context refers to individual life and the seat of one's personality. The altars being dug down represented a complete destruction, indicating a time of great distress and declension in religion. The plural form of altars points to the high places in Israel, where Jehovah was publicly worshiped. Overall, Elijah's statement expressed not just the belief that he was the only prophet remaining, but also the only true worshiper of Jehovah.

Elijah's declaration of being the sole survivor conveys a sense of isolation. The word 'soul' refers to the seat of individual life and personality. The demolished altars signify a period of distress and religious decline. The plural form of altars refers to high places in Israel where Jehovah was publicly worshiped. Elijah believed he was the only remaining prophet and the sole true worshiper of Jehovah. This verse captures a moment of deep solitude and the fervent devotion of Elijah amidst challenging times.

Elijah's feeling of solitude is evident in his statement I only am left. The word 'soul' denotes individual existence and the seat of one's personality. The destroyed altars symbolize a time of distress and religious decline. The plural altars signify the high places in Israel where Jehovah was worshipped. Elijah believed he was the sole remaining prophet and the only true worshiper of Jehovah. This passage highlights his profound loneliness and unwavering devotion amid challenging circumstances.

Elijah's sense of isolation is evident as he proclaims, I only am left. The word 'soul' refers to the distinctness of individual existence, while 'altars' indicates the places where Jehovah was worshiped. Elijah believed he was the lone prophet and the true worshiper of Jehovah. This verse captures his deep solitude and unwavering devotion in the face of adversity.
